displayed_text: Family Member: No. Patient: Yeah. I remember him saying that. Doctor: Yeah. I wouldn’t say that. There’s no number that, huh, I can tell you there’s no number that I get excited about. Family Member 1: He said if the number went up too many times, he would check the scans because he doesn’t go by the number. The number just shows that that medicine wasn’t necessary. Patient: I wonder how long I’ve had this damn cancer. Doctor: And you get your blood work Quest LabCorp here? Patient: B___. Family Member: B___. Doctor: And you got it the same day you saw me or you got, you went over there earlier today or-? Family Member: He got it done here today. They made an appointment here today. Doctor: Okay. Huh, but normally you go to B___? Family Member: Yes.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s very common to see cancer cells along the nerves. Family Member: And the nerves came out with the vesicles? Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Um is it any better that the extra prosthetic extension is a pattern three instead of a four? Doctor: Maybe. Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: That vaccine therapies tend to work a little better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So with that, that’s why I think it would be a great next stop to do. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We would have to get clearance from insurance because it’s about a hundred thousand bucks. Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up.

Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow. Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse.

Patient: As needed. Doctor: The Lisinopril twenty milligrams day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Metoprolol a hundred milligrams a day. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Mometasone or Nasonex sprays. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: No, that’s been set up for ten milligrams, and that’s as needed now after it’s been about two weeks since my radiation. Doctor: So it’s that ten milligram pill you take? Patient: No it’s two fives. Doctor: Oh, yeah. The OxyContin? And the OxyContin is thirty milligrams twice a day? Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now.

Patient: Okay. So, the bloodwork I did today. What was that for? Doctor: That was for me to feel good about myself. No, uh. That was mostly looking at PSA. Patient: Again? Doctor: I think that – That was today’s blood. So. Family Member: So, they had a PSA. Patient: We did, we did. Doctor: No, no, what did you have today? Yeah. Well, I, I think that’s also part of this is getting me and the radiation folks together ‘cuz I think we’re ordering redundant now. I mean, they ordered a test; I ordered a test. You know, we’re, we need to kind of Patient: Okay. Doctor: Get one test, one doctor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you probably didn’t need to have another PSA test this soon, but we got one. Family Member: Okay. Well that’s fine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm. Patient: Cancer. The cancer subsided or it can't reverse cancer get worse. Doctor: The cancer has gotten worse and moved on to new spots or new areas. Oh, you know, it's not gonna be shy. It'll tell us. Yeah. So at this moment is just sort of the slow creep, you know, it’s the- What do you mean? It's six right? I mean, you haven't way in the beginning you were near 300 there but you've always been super low. So when we look at you, it's like this tiny little rises but nothing that's like this. Yeah, Patient: Just a quick note- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - it started out much higher than that. I think you get Doctor: Yeah, no, no, I had you correct. Yeah, we met each other after your stuff started but in our system, that's as high as you been?

Patient: Right. Doctor: And so that would be something that you know, based on sort of, if we really think T12 is real or T3 is real, that could be something that we would send you off to the radiation doctors to have them talk about that trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then we get the PET scan and it actually says, you know, you've got 123 plus 456, you know, that we think most of this is real, we can step back and watch a little bit longer until either declares itself a little bit more. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or just say hey, it's there. And then we have a couple studies where the current standard for the guy who shows up with multiple spots is to go on hormones for life. Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: It wasn't really great in detail. Doctor: Okay, so this is the, this is the consent form for the MAP trial. So this is the MAP trial phase three, meaning that it's just more advanced and we're comparing it against placebo and it's a large trial. So I want you to take this home, I want you to read it, and I want you to think about it. I'll contact our research nurses too to see if you're eligible. And then we'll give you a call tomorrow and you can tell me. Yes, I think this is reasonable. Let's keep going. You can tell me- Patient: Trust me, I don’t have to wait until next week. Family Member: Trust me, he'll sign it right now. Patient: I’m serious. Family Member: I mean, he's ready to go. We kind of talked about it. Okay. Doctor: You know, so what were the discussion or what were you thinking or what were the discussions that you were having before? Family Member: Well, I was telling him about what N___ did for friend of mine and what he went through Doctor: Mm okay. Family Member: a lot of a prostrate clinical trials study also. Doctor: Oh okay. Family Member: So I went with him. You know, while he started the process, Doctor: Oh okay.

Family Member 1: Monitored. Doctor: Yeah, monitored. And if it's the worst thing you've ever done, stop, start over on something else. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: If you feel fine, and you continue, then thumbs up. So it's a work in progress, really, for all of us. But I think if we just keep communicating, we'll do right by you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so my next step, honestly, is to get M____ in here so that we can just get the timing and things right and logistics. Family Member 1: So we're not starting nothing today. Doctor: No, because this isn't that you know, that oral pill is investigational. So you- the first thing we have to do is have you sign the right papers and make sure that whatever we just discussed, yep, get it get the copy at home, just so everybody's on the same page. Family Member 3: When does it start? Doctor: So we're hoping to start within a couple of weeks or but you know, or even sooner, because there’s that time crunch. Family Member 1: It worries me that, it’s aggressive, his cancer. Doctor: It is. It is. Family Member 1: So with him walking around, not on anything that is upsetting me.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time? Doctor: Yeah me and if people live around her they see me. If you know have a relationship with Dr. F__ and that’s closer. Family Member: I would like to keep you both though because I think you know it would be more convenient to be close to home and I know they have state-of-the-art equipment there because I’ve already talked to the manager of the cancer center and um and then to still be coming here. To me it is. If that’s okay with you. Doctor: Do you want me to send him a text right now? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah? (pause) Family Member: That’s fine. Patient: Yeah that’s fine. Family Member: That’s fine because I could set up an appointment with him to just kind of go over things and I don’t know when they’ll want him to start. Doctor: When your control is better. Family Member: Do we decide that or do we come see you again first? Doctor: You decide it with Dr. F___ but don’t rush into it. Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So I think that is something to track down obviously, but um we’ll have to see how it goes. I’m just hoping you know we definitely have the Lynparza sort of as a fall back. Um again- Patient: So I’d be two steps away from chemo. Doctor: But getting that as well not quite and who knows how many more steps we’ll find as we go along, you know. Like I said this BET inhibitor wasn’t there what six months ago if you had needed this option and it wasn’t there for you. So it’s changed very rapidly. Patient: Everything is brand new. Doctor: Yeah but obviously we should jump on that if we can. Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial?

Family Member: They are cold. Doctor: Okay! What are we going to do? (chair movement) Family Member: Can you -- I’m lost here. Can you repeat – uh, why -- are you saying that he could go on the next trial? Doctor: You could try a trial and see how you do – Patient: Right. Doctor: And then, if somewhere along the way, it improves, great. I’m talkin’ about the fistula and this whole – Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could not and just go straight to surgery, do the re-routing that we talked about last time – Patient: Right. Doctor: And do the study after. Either way, the comforting part is there is a potential next treatment that is – Patient: Okay. So, so how come I can’t do, do the pills and do the treatment, too? Can I do both? Doctor: No, no, no. You could the, you could do the pills.

Patient: Yes, I have, you know. Doctor: Yes, thank you for that. Patient: You’re the doctor. I’m never gonna deny that. Doctor: Yeah, thank you for coming back and just sort of, you know, they’re like do you want to come, I’m like no, it’s too complicated to have this conversation on the phone. I want them here so we have a plan. Plus, I was a little worried about your pain. Patient: Yeah, okay. I appreciate that. Doctor: Yeah, which is now kind of making me think that maybe, you know, the stuff in the bone is just sort of acting up and has really, we passed the biopsy sort of situation. I mean this should be better. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having sharp pains every day right where his appendix scar is. He doesn’t have an appendix. Doctor: Doc Yeah, mmm hm. Family Member: He had it taken out fifty years ago. Patient: It just started. Family Member: Just the last five or six days he’s had sharp pain. Doctor: Are you constipated?
